sen.e: According to one theory for the origin of this word, it was the god of fire that appeared in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) named Kagutsuchi (Honokagutsuchinokami or god of fire, who burned the vagina and killed Izanami during birth before being chopped to pieces by Izanagi and its pieces turned into gods, and its name changed from "加具士=>加具師=>香具師 (yashi)."

sen.j: 「無職渡世」とは本来、職業が公認されない博徒を指し、的屋について言われることはなかった。
sen.e: Mushoku tose' (live on gambling without working) originally referred to a gambler with an unofficial job and did not apply to tekiya.

sen.e: The territory of tekiya that makes it as a job for living is called as 'niwaba' while bakuto refers to it as 'island.'

sen.j: また上記概要にも記述があるが、個々の信仰は別として的屋は職業神として神農を祀り博徒は職業神として天照大神を祀っている。
sen.e: There are many documents that refer to what was phrased above, but tekiya worshipped Shinno and bakuto worshipped Amaterasu Okami as the business god.

sen.j: 組織として「組」を形成し互助活動を行っていた。
sen.e: It performed mutual aid activities as a 'group' within the society.
They were formed along the lines of the traditional Japanese "kumi" and acted as mutual assistance associations.
They were formed along the lines of the traditional Japanese 'kumi' (an organization) and acted as mutual assistance associations.

sen.j: これは的屋特有のものではなく、大工、鳶、土方（つちかた）などの建設業団体や河岸、沖仲仕、舟方（ふなかた）などの港湾労働団体や籠屋、渡し、馬方（うまかた）などの運輸荷役団体と同じである。
sen.e: This was not designated to tekiya and called as carpenter, tobi (kite), or tsuchikata (laborer)

This was not unique to tekiya, with construction associations made up of carpenters, scaffolders, and tsuchikata (also known as doteninsoku, these were groups of civil engineers involved in land reclamation and levee protection projects in the Edo Period), longshoreman associations consisting of river bank and dock workers and transport associations consisting of messengers, palanquin bearers and ferrymen all formed along similar lines.
sen.cmt: *Although this sentence and the following one were treated as separate sentences, they are actually one sentence so I revised as such.
sen.e: This was not unique to tekiya, with construction associations made up of carpenters, scaffolders, and tsuchikata (also known as doteninsoku, these were groups of civil engineers involved in land reclamation and levee protection projects in the Edo Period), longshoreman associations consisting of river bank and dock workers, ferrymen and so on, and transport associations consisting of messengers, palanquin bearers and packhorse drivers, and so on, all formed along similar lines.
sen.cmt: ウェブ内の脚注文章が含まれていたため、原文・訳文共に修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、互助活動に対しての謝礼の授受が今でいう民事介入と言う表現になりやくざと同一視される由縁である。
sen.e: Its mutual aid system became associated with involvement with society and is viewed to be the same as yakuza.

However, the system of rewards that existed as part of their mutual assistance actvities developed into what is now called 'minji kainyu' (essentially protection rackets) and which is associated with the yakuza.

sen.j: 各地の神農会を構成、運営していた「庭主」（世話役のこと）も、諸事情により その円滑な運営をなしえない状態にあるものもある。
sen.e: There were cases where 'Teishu' (head of the garden) (the care-taker) that formed the Shinno Association of each district and could not manage it due to various reasons.

There were cases where, for various reasons, the 'teishu' (literally 'head of the garden', they were kind of stewards), who organized and managed the Shinno Association of each district, was unable to ensure smooth operations.

There were cases where, for various reasons, the 'niwanushi' (literally 'head of the niwaba,' they were kind of stewards), who organized and managed the Shinno Association of each district, was unable to ensure smooth operations.
sen.cmt: 用語の読み等を修正しました。

sen.j: 本来、行商人や旅人（たびにん）の場所の確保や世話をする世話人が集まって組織となり神農会と呼ばれる庭主（組合）が起こったが、現在では、そのほとんどが各地の暴力団の傘下組織となり、一部には本来一番肝心な世話することを怠って何もしない「庭主」が「○○会○代目」、「○○組分家」、「○○会○○一家」と名乗り、競合する出店を脅迫し排除したり、挨拶に来るよう呼びつけ行商人などから着到（その地区の世話人に世話になる場合、到着した際に挨拶として持っていく手土産）名目で金品をたかる組織も存在する。
sen.e: The Shinno Association of teishu (union) was formed by gathering caretakers of travelling merchants or travelers that reserved and managed the spot, but most of them went under the rule of local mafia that some had 'teishu' without any particular duty that call themselves as '-the generation of -- society,' '-family of -- society,' or '--society -- family' and took away money when inviting merchants to greet them (as a gift given to a caretaker in appreciation for help) after arriving to the local district.

Originally, unions of teishu, known as Shinno Associations, were formed by groups of mediators who secured spots for and looked after peddlars and travelers, but these days, most are affiliated with criminal gangs, with some 'teishu' completely ignoring the 'taking care of' part, which was originally the most important, and while claiming to be the 'n-th teishu of such-and-such society' or from 'a branch of so-and-so kumi' or 'the such-and-such family of so-and-so society', they threaten and exclude rivals and demand gifts and money from from newly-arrived merchants seeking their services.

Originally, unions of niwanushi, known as Shinno Associations, were formed by groups of mediators who secured spots for and looked after peddlers and travelers, but these days, most are affiliated with criminal gangs, with some 'niwanushi' completely ignoring the 'taking care of' part, which was originally the most important, and while claiming to be the 'n-th niwanushi of such-and-such society' or from 'a branch of so-and-so kumi' or 'the such-and-such family of so-and-so society,' they threaten and exclude rivals and demand gifts and money in the name of chakuto (gifts for caretakers of the area when merchants arrived, in a sign of greeting) from newly-arrived merchants seeking their services.

sen.j: 現在では一部地域において県の公認を受けた協同組合として活動している組織もある。
sen.e: There are some societies that participate after given permission from the prefecture for certain regions.

sen.e: Even with this case, there are chief or chair of certain society that has an additional job as a director of a certain union that it is not really a group of union but a privately owned group.

Even in this case, the director of the cooperative is usually also a gang boss or the president of some society, meaning that rather than associations for cooperation, they are associations for the boss's benefit.
